characters: THROWS THE KID OFF THE BIKE
A BIRD HITS THE WINDSHIELD OF HIS CAR

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: OPEN on green hills, hidden under mysterious swathes of ground fog. There’s an eerie quiet as the sun sinks and the shadows lengthen... PAN DOWN to a “Welcome To Sawville, Population 2649” sign. The city’s motto, “We Came, We Sawed, We Prospered” scrolls over a cartoon image of a sawmill. Suddenly, an entire 12 pack of EGGS splat the sign, yolk dripping as we HEAR METAL MUSIC and a KID WHOOPING over the ROAR of a pick-up truck.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: In the truck, two teenagers (CLAYTON and JEFF) roar down a back road. Jeff, wearing an EVIL DEAD tee shirt, is driving. As they approach a row of

dialogues.speaker: RURAL MAIL BOXES,
dialogues.text: Clayton, sporting a John Deere cap, finishes a beer, tosses the empty and grabs a baseball bat from behind the driver’s seat, noticing a pile of DVDs and comic books.

dialogues.speaker: CLAYTON
dialogues.text: Thought I told you to ditch all this monster movie stuff.

dialogues.speaker: JEFF
dialogues.text: What’s wrong with it?

dialogues.speaker: CLAYTON
dialogues.text: Sheesus, Jeff... As they pass the mailboxes Clayton leans out the window and swings, smashing the boxes and sending plumes of letters into the air. CLAYTON (CONT’D) Mail’s in! (back to Jeff) ..+.-when are you going to grow up? I’m trying to get you laid, but how’s that going to happen when first thing the chick sees is... (grabs DVD) (MORE ) (CONTINUED )

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Verheiden "My Name Is Bruce" 4/2/06 2.

dialogues.speaker: CLAYTON, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: .»+.some piece of shit starring “Bruce Campbell”...

dialogues.speaker: JEFF
dialogues.text: What did you say...?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Jeff suddenly SLAMS ON THE BRAKES and the truck fishtails to a stop, dust washing up over the cab.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: As Clayton lurches forward then back, Jeff glares him.

dialogues.speaker: JEFF
dialogues.text: Take it back.

dialogues.speaker: CLAYTON
dialogues.text: What?

dialogues.speaker: JEFF
dialogues.text: Bruce Campbell is the greatest actor of his generation!

dialogues.speaker: CLAYTON
dialogues.text: You're kidding, right? (going through boxes) “Mindtrap?” “Alien Apocalypse?” “Cavealien?”

dialogues.speaker: JEFF
dialogues.text: (defensive) Shut up! That’s a good one! Clayton flips the box, dramatically reading the blurb.

dialogues.speaker: CLAYTON
dialogues.text: “Bruce Campbell IS Lt. Jack Stryker, a rogue clone-warrior and mankind’s last hope against the deadly Cavealiens.”

dialogues.speaker: JEFF
dialogues.text: Yeah? So?

dialogues.speaker: CLAYTON
dialogues.text: Dude, forget thumbs, Ebert wouldn’t wipe his crack with this trash! Jeff grabs the DVD away from him, angry. (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Verheiden "My Name Is Bruce" 4/2/06 3.

dialogues.speaker: JEFF
dialogues.text: Get out of the truck.

dialogues.speaker: CLAYTON
dialogues.text: Whoa, slow down...

dialogues.speaker: JEFF
dialogues.text: You don’t like Bruce, you walk.

dialogues.speaker: CLAYTON
dialogues.text: I loved Army Of Darkness!

dialogues.speaker: JEFF
dialogues.text: Everybody loved that one! (anger abating) But... all right.

dialogues.speaker: CLAYTON
dialogues.text: (a *whew* ) Now, could we please go get laid? Jeff begrudgingly puts the truck into gear, headlights stabbing the shadows as they careen down the dusty road.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: TIME PASSES and the truck’s headlights wash across the dilapidated arches of an old GRAVEYARD. As the truck rolls through the arches, pan across another

dialogues.speaker: OLD, HALF-ROTTED SIGN
dialogues.text: identifying this new location cryptically with some painted Asian characters, along with a few broken English words of warning: PRO ECTE FO THOSE WH DIE . BEWA E HOSE WITHOUT EAN URD. ("Protected for those who died. Beware those without bean curd.”) As HEADLIGHTS stab the moonlit darkness, Jeff's pick-up SMASHES OVER the sign and skids to a stop. PULL OUT to reveal a DILAPIDATED CHINESE GRAVEYARD, nestled in the shadow of a tall hill. Rotted sticks with faded Chinese characters jut from the ground. Barely visible somewhere in the background is a long abandoned mine-shaft, barely visible in the mountainside. After a moment, JEFF STEPS OUT OF THE TRUCK, flashlight in hand. The BEAM dances through the darkness and across the grave markers, some tagged with wisps of tattered cloth, others broken and jagged. As Jeff moves up to one of the markers, staring at it... (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Verheiden "My Name Is Bruce" 4/2/06 4.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Jeff JUMPS UP with a SCREAM and turns his light, revealing LITTLE DEBBIE. A creepy teenage Goth chick with multiple piercings and heavy mascara.

dialogues.speaker: LITTLE DEBBIE
dialogues.text: You scream like a girl. Next to her looms another teenager, BIG DEBBIE. She's REAL big, well over six feet. Their car’s parked nearby, hidden by the darkness. LITTLE DEBBIE (CONT’D) (eying graves) Come on, Big Debbie. lLet’s check it out. The Debbies exchange excited “let’s check it out!” looks and bolt to explore the graveyard.

dialogues.speaker: JEFF
dialogues.text: Who are they?

dialogues.speaker: CLAYTON
dialogues.text: Big Debbie and Little Debbie. From the Apple Festival.

dialogues.speaker: JEFF
dialogues.text: I thought they blew us off.

dialogues.speaker: CLAYTON
dialogues.text: They blew you off, “Evil Dead.” (nods at Goth girl) When I told the Mascara Queen about this old boneyard she practically dry-humped me on the spot.

dialogues.speaker: JEFF
dialogues.text: She’s kind of cute. Clayton notices Jeff's anxious/horny look.

dialogues.speaker: CLAYTON
dialogues.text: Don’t worry, hard-on. Morticia’s all yours. (eyes on Big Debbie) I’m going human fly on that skyscraper. As they follow the girls into the graveyard, Goth “Little Debbie” hesitates, looking across the stones. (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Verheiden "My Name Is Bruce" 4/2/06 5.

dialogues.speaker: CONTINUED
dialogues.text: CLAYTON (CONT’D) The graves haven’t been touched in years. We’re all alone out here.

dialogues.speaker: LITTLE DEBBIE
dialogues.text: (reverent) It looks ancient. Historic. This place must have meant a lot to these people. Suddenly Little Debbie gleefully KICKS DOWN a grave marker. LITTLE DEBBIE (CONT’D) Let’s break something!

dialogues.speaker: JEFF
dialogues.text: As long as it’s not my heart. Jeff makes his move on Goth Little Debbie. He’s doing a faux Bruce Campbell riff, but Little Debbie, stomping apart ancient grave markers, couldn’t care less.

dialogues.speaker: JEFF, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: What do you say? Gimme some sugar, baby.

dialogues.speaker: LITTLE DEBBIE
dialogues.text: What? Jeff gets in front of her. Working it.

dialogues.speaker: JEFF
dialogues.text: Come on. We can dance the “hard to get” all night, but if this game’s called eye-tag... Jeff takes Little Debbie in his arms, staring with smoldering Campbell-esque intensity into her eyes.

dialogues.speaker: JEFF, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: .-»-your lips say I’m “it.” Little Debbie stares at him, almost like she’s succumbing, then she suddenly SPITS her gum in his face. As it bounces off his nose, Jeff releases Little Debbie and she runs across the graveyard.

dialogues.speaker: JEFF, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Mmm. Juicy Fruit. As the girls move off, laughing and throwing “you freak” looks at Jeff, Clayton leans close to Jeff. (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Verheiden "My Name Is Bruce" 4/2/06 6.

dialogues.speaker: CLAYTON
dialogues.text: Smoooooth, “Brucie.” Clayton takes off across the old graveyard with the Debbies, laughing as they vandalize more Chinese graves. Jeff just stands there, struggling to maintain his Campbell-esque cool.

dialogues.speaker: JEFF
dialogues.text: Your loss, baby. Your loss... Grumpy, Jeff picks up his flashlight and continues across the graveyard, stumbling toward an OLD MINE SHAFT. Broken timbers surround a landslide of boulders that have completely blocked the entrance. As his flashlight washes across the rocks, something GLISTENS. Jeff turns, like he wants to tell the others he’s found something, but in the GRAVEYARD all he can see are flickers of flashlights, dancing across the darkness, and distant, mocking VOICES.

dialogues.speaker: CLAYTON, (0.S.)
dialogues.text: (distant) “Here lies Hung Far Low, he dug too deep, no Low no-mo...” As LAUGHTER rings across the old graveyard, Jeff kneels and grabs at the shiny object, pulling. It’s jammed in tight, some sort of SHINY AMULET. While Clayton and the girls continue to yell in the darkness, Jeff pulls harder, really putting himself into it, finally YANKING the amulet free. As Jeff rolls back on his ass, CAMERA pushes through the small hole into the avalanche of rocks...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Camera zooms in through the rock-slide, around wet cave walls, past a broken HUMAN SKULL, until it closes on dark red circle. It might just be a strange formation in the rock, until TWO RED DEMONIC EYES SUDDENLY OPEN.  Verheiden "My Name Is Bruce" 4/2/06 7.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Jeff backs away from the rock wall, studying the amulet with his flashlight as he moves back into the graveyard. Closer examination shows some faded CHINESE ETCHINGS in the metal, and a glowering demonic face.

dialogues.speaker: JEFF
dialogues.text: Groovy. Suddenly, Jeff hears the faint rumble of falling rock just behind him. Surprised, Jeff turns and shines his light on the face of the MINE SHAFT. A few pebbles and a puff of dust roll down. Doesn’t look like much, and after watching for a second, Jeff shrugs and looks back toward the graveyard.

dialogues.speaker: JEFF, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Hey -- ! OUT OF FOCUS, behind Jeff, more rocks move as something seems to be clawing free from the rubble. Jeff turns, his eyes going wide as the rocks rumble free and there’s an awful, unearthly ROAR.

dialogues.speaker: OH CHRIST SHIT
dialogues.text: Terrified, Jeff bolts, tucking the talisman in his pocket as he scrambles toward the GRAVEYARD. Hearing Jeff's cries, Clayton (his hand clamped firmly on Big Debbie’s boob) and the two girls look over, assuming it’s a prank.

dialogues.speaker: CLAYTON
dialogues.text: Son of a...

dialogues.speaker: YOUR LIVES
dialogues.text: As Jeff races by, an oblivious Clayton continues to fondle Big Debbie.

dialogues.speaker: CLAYTON
dialogues.text: Wha... Suddenly a SWORD SWOOSHES across frame. BLOOD SPRAYS. Stunned, Big Debbie looks down at the hand still clutching her boob, and realizes it’s been (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Verheiden "My Name Is Bruce" 4/2/06 8.

dialogues.speaker: CONTINUED
dialogues.text: CHOPPED OFF AT THE WRIST! As she SCREAMS, the mystic blade suddenly SLASHES across her throat, blood gushing from the wound. JEFF races toward the pick-up as Big Debbie’s scream stops. Suddenly something large and bloody FLIES over his head, CRASHING WITH A GOOEY SPLAT against the back of the truck. As Jeff runs up, his flashlight finds Little Debbie’s broken, bloodied body lying in a heap. Sticks of Juicy Fruit spilling from her coat pocket.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Scared, Jeff jumps into the truck, fumbling for the keys. He fires it up, engine roaring, reaching for the gearshift when CLAYTON staggers to the window, smearing the glass with blood gushing from his severed arm, clearly in shock.

dialogues.speaker: CLAYTON
dialogues.text: Don’t leave me, man!

dialogues.speaker: AHHHH
dialogues.text: There’s another unearthly ROAR from the released DEMON. Terrified, Jeff PUNCHES IT. As the truck tears gravel, a scared Jeff looks in the rearview and sees CLAYTON staggering in the dust, illuminated by the truck’s red tail lights. As Clayton staggers, arm gushing blood, a large FIGURE surrounded by swirling, windswept robes, RAISES A SWORD... IN THE TRUCK Jeff can’t look as he drives crazily, Bruce Campbell DVD’s sliding around on the seat...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: TIGHT on Bruce Campbell, shouting into the darkness.

dialogues.speaker: BRUCE
dialogues.text: Hold it right there! (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Verheiden "My Name Is Bruce" 4/2/06 9.

dialogues.speaker: CONTINUED
dialogues.text: For an instant, we think Bruce is yelling at Jeff. But then we pull back, revealing that Bruce is wearing some quasi-futuristic coveralls (CAVE PATROL patch on the shoulder) and he’s yelling at PETRA, a sultry blonde with a thick Russian accent, wearing the same uniform.

dialogues.speaker: PETRA
dialogues.text: Vat’s wrong vith you, Stryker? We've got the Cavealien cornered! (“Cavealien” is pronounced as one word.) PULL BACK to reveal Bruce and Petra standing out a cave opening, totally unlike the mine shaft at the beginning.

dialogues.speaker: BRUCE
dialogues.text: So transmit the scans up to Delta- Baker, plant some bio-blasters and send out for Chinese. Your Colonial Jarheads can handle the shake and bake.

dialogues.speaker: PETRA
dialogues.text: Col. Packer’s still trapped down there! Bruce throws a sarcastic look toward the cave.

dialogues.speaker: BRUCE
dialogues.text: Knew there was a reason I got up this morning.

dialogues.speaker: PETRA
dialogues.text: You bastard!

dialogues.speaker: BRUCE
dialogues.text: Hey! Last time I saw Packer he tried to put me in front of a firing squad! Petra SLAPS Bruce across the face.

dialogues.speaker: PETRA
dialogues.text: Coward! I should have left you on Regula Nine! As she swings to slap him again, Bruce catches her hand.

dialogues.speaker: BRUCE
dialogues.text: We both know you couldn’t do that. Petra doesn’t pull away. Her expression says she knows Bruce is right. (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Verheiden "My Name Is Bruce" 4/2/06 10.

dialogues.speaker: PETRA
dialogues.text: I still can’t believe a loser like you vas cloned from one of my dead husband's cells.

dialogues.speaker: BRUCE
dialogues.text: That’s right, baby. They built me out of your old man’s DNA. So how about we share a little, mouth to mouth?

dialogues.speaker: PETRA
dialogues.text: You’re dees-gusting.

dialogues.speaker: BRUCE
dialogues.text: I’m aman. And I've been wanting to do this ever since we landed on this rock. As Bruce kisses her, Petra reluctantly, then enthusiastically accepts his kiss. The erotic moment interrupted by a gurgling NOISE off screen.

dialogues.speaker: PETRA
dialogues.text: What the -- Bruce whips out his “blaster.”

dialogues.speaker: BRUCE
dialogues.text: Dammit! They’re all around us! Petra throws a sarcastic look at Bruce.

dialogues.speaker: PETRA
dialogues.text: Vooks like you get to play soldier- boy after all! A gelatinous MONSTER suddenly appears behind Petra, rubbery tendrils flailing. Bruce aims his futuristic blaster and FIRES A SPARKY BLAST into the beast. Hit, the monster ejaculates a great spew of alien goo. A gout hits Bruce in the face and he reacts with disgust, then SURPRISE as MORE and MORE alien glop geysers from the monster's wound.

dialogues.speaker: BRUCE
dialogues.text: Je-sus H... Bruce raises his hands to fend off the ridiculous amount of “alien blood.” (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Verheiden "My Name Is Bruce" 4/2/06 11.

dialogues.speaker: BRUCE, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Easy on the ichor! I think we get the point!

dialogues.speaker: DIRECTOR
dialogues.text: Okay, cut! PULL BACK to reveal the cave is actually a low budget movie set for the movie CAVEALIEN (cave-alien) 2. The DIRECTOR, a younger guy with a boyish attitude and glasses a half inch thick, walks onto the set as Bruce coughs up the last of the alien goo.

dialogues.speaker: DIRECTOR, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: That was aces, Bruce. Nice work. The myopic Director keeps walking, running head first into a fake tree. He bounces back, like this happens all the time.

dialogues.speaker: BRUCE
dialogues.text: (wiping off goo) You didn’t think it was a little over the top? The Director blinks behind his thick glasses.

dialogues.speaker: DIRECTOR
dialogues.text: It’s Cavealien 2.

dialogues.speaker: BRUCE
dialogues.text: That’s not an answer.

dialogues.speaker: DIRECTOR
dialogues.text: Did you see Cavealien 1? As the Director moves on, Bruce notices an overweight male P.A. standing by craft services.

dialogues.speaker: BRUCE
dialogues.text: Hey, Tiny. Fetch me a lemon water, will ya? The P.A. grabs a bottle from a nearby cooler and quickly passes it over. Bruce gives the bottle a glance and tosses it back at the P.A., annoyed.

dialogues.speaker: BRUCE, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Lemon. Le-mon. (as P.A. hesitates) Let’s go, Jumbo! Ondelay, ondelay! (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Verheiden "My Name Is Bruce" 4/2/06 12.

dialogues.speaker: CONTINUED
dialogues.text: The annoyed P.A. moves off toward a craft services cart as Petra comes up. Bruce continues to “drip” goo through- out this scene.

dialogues.speaker: BRUCE, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Hey, baby, nice work. On a show this down and dirty, it’s a relief to be working with a professional. Even out of character, Petra has the Russian accent.

dialogues.speaker: PETRA
dialogues.text: (withering) I vouldn’t know. Bruce raises his hands, “take it easy” style, accidentally spattering her with goo.

dialogues.speaker: BRUCE
dialogues.text: Easy, Quick-Draw. We’re both on the same page.

dialogues.speaker: PETRA
dialogues.text: Veally.

dialogues.speaker: BRUCE
dialogues.text: Sure, baby. Low budget show like this is just a detour. A quick cash infusion while Scorsese and Spielberg are warming up our chairs.

dialogues.speaker: PETRA
dialogues.text: Who? Bruce blinks.

dialogues.speaker: BRUCE
dialogues.text: Sounds like you could use a little filmmaking 101. Lucky for you, the Professor is in. (seductive) I know this little bar off Cahuenga where the drinks are cheap and the barmaids are cheaper... BRRRING. Petra gets a call on her cell. She takes it, cutting Bruce off in mid-sentence.

dialogues.speaker: PETRA
dialogues.text: Hullo? Vhy yes! (eying Bruce) (MORE ) (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Verheiden "My Name Is Bruce" 4/2/06 13.

dialogues.speaker: PETRA, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: No, you're not ee-nterrupting anything. As Petra wanders off, cooing into her phone...

dialogues.speaker: BRUCE
dialogues.text: (calling after her) Think it over! Bruce looks out across the location, hands on his hips, “in charge”, as the D.P. adjusts the lens on the camera.

dialogues.speaker: BRUCE, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Jimmy. I’m thinking we should go with a ‘50 for this next shot. D.P. Got one up your ass?

dialogues.speaker: BRUCE
dialogues.text: (considers, then) Maybe a ‘75? As Bruce continues to “consider” lens choices, TINY THE ANGRY P.A. is standing to one side, grinning evilly as he pees lemon-green urine into an empty “Lemon Water” bottle. OFF this...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Bruce, dressed in gaudy civilian clothes as shooting wraps for the day, exits the soundstage, only to find himself suddenly surrounded by a gaggle of devoted FANS. Practically wetting themselves in Bruce’s presence. Geek central. NO GIRLS. Not in the mood for a fan encounter, Bruce forces a wan smile as he wades through them.

dialogues.speaker: FANS
dialogues.text: Bruce! Mr. Campbell! Ash! Always prepared, Bruce whips out a stack of 8 x 10’s and starts dealing them out like a poker player.

dialogues.speaker: BRUCE
dialogues.text: Here ya go, one for you, one for you, Holy Mother of God what’s that smell -- As the fan in front of Bruce cluelessly sniffs his own armpits, Bruce reaches in his pocket and hands him a stick of Right Guard. (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Verheiden "My Name Is Bruce" 4/2/06 14.

dialogues.speaker: BRUCE, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: It’s called deodorant. Look it up on your “internets.” (passing more photos) Don’t worry, I’ve got enough for all you little trolls... A fan in a wheelchair rolls up and Bruce hands him a photo. The Wheelchair Fan thrusts it right back, mega- demanding.

dialogues.speaker: WHEELCHAIR FAN
dialogues.text: Mr. Campbell! Mr. Campbell! How about an autograph? The Wheelchair Fan holds out Bruce’s 8 x 10, but there’s no pen.

dialogues.speaker: WHEELCHAIR FAN, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: What, no pen? Bruce rolls his eyes and slides out a pen, scrawling his signature.

dialogues.speaker: WHEELCHAIR FAN, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Say cheese! Before Bruce can answer, he’s BLINDED by a flash.

dialogues.speaker: BRUCE
dialogues.text: Gahhhh!

dialogues.speaker: WHEELCHAIR FAN
dialogues.text: How about five bucks for the bus? Blinking, his eyes clearing, Bruce glares at the kid.

dialogues.speaker: BRUCE
dialogues.text: Ever hear the theme from “Rawhide?”

dialogues.speaker: WHEELCHAIR FAN
dialogues.text: Huh? Bruce lifts his foot and gives the fan’s wheelchair a shove, sending him rolling backward down the sidewalk.

dialogues.speaker: BRUCE
dialogues.text: “Keep them doggies rollin’...” As Bruce continues ahead, he’s trailed by the fans and peppered with more inane questions. (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Verheiden "My Name Is Bruce" 4/2/06 15.

dialogues.speaker: SECOND DEVOTED FAN
dialogues.text: When you were trapped in the pit in ARMY OF DARKNESS, how did you get your shotgun?

dialogues.speaker: THIRD DEVOTED FAN
dialogues.text: When you kissed “Ellen” did it turn you gay?

dialogues.speaker: FOURTH DEVOTED FAN
dialogues.text: How much wood could a woodchuck chuck?

dialogues.speaker: BRUCE
dialogues.text: Who cares, absolutely not and three cubic board feet... (shoving through) Gotta run, boys, I’m late for a soiree. Bruce maneuvers around to his car, a battered Ford Pinto. As he slides in and slams the door, the fans continue to assail him with inane questions, one of them even getting in front of the car. Bruce GUNS IT ANYWAY, plowing right into the guy, who shouts his question even as he’s tumbling across the hood...

dialogues.speaker: DEVOTED FAN
dialogues.text: Mr. Campbell, Mr. Camp... (WOMP! He’s hit!) ...bellAHHHH... As Bruce ROARS OFF, we can see his fans running after him (or, in the case of the one who’s been hit, stumbling and clutching his injured leg), shouting more questions... DEVOTED FAN (CONT’D) Mr. CampOWWW, Mr. CampOWWW...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hollywood Blvd. Bruce screams up to the UNIFORMED VALET in his Pinto, tossing the valet his keys.

dialogues.speaker: BRUCE
dialogues.text: Park her close, chief. This won’t take long.  Verheiden "My Name Is Bruce" 4/2/06 16.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Bruce enters the busy restaurant, face sour as he looks for someone. As he passes the bar, the BARTENDER shoots him a knowing look.

dialogues.speaker: BRUCE
dialogues.text: Gimme a bourbon with a loaded revolver back. Bruce continues into the restaurant itself, spotting MILLS TODDNER sitting alone at a table, talking on his cell-phone and flipping through the trades. As Bruce walks up, he points at the Variety.

dialogues.speaker: BRUCE, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Hear I made the trades today.

dialogues.speaker: MILLS
dialogues.text: Really?

dialogues.speaker: BRUCE
dialogues.text: Yeah. My career’s in the obituaries. Mills closes his phone and rises, laughing at Bruce’s “joke”, giving him a big Hollywood hug and kiss.

dialogues.speaker: MILLS
dialogues.text: Give me some sugar, baby. As Bruce disdainfully accepts the hug...

dialogues.speaker: MILLS, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: (re: phone) That was the studio. They’re crazy over the dailies from Cavealien 2. Said you've never been better.

dialogues.speaker: BRUCE
dialogues.text: I speak English. In their world that makes me Meryl banana-sucking Streep. The Bartender arrives at the table and puts a huge tumbler of bourbon in front of Bruce.

dialogues.speaker: BARTENDER
dialogues.text: Will that be cash, Mr. Campbell? (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Verheiden "My Name Is Bruce" 4/2/06 17.

dialogues.speaker: BRUCE
dialogues.text: No. My agent Mr. Toddner will be picking this one up. Mills’ frown suggests he clearly wasn’t planning on buying, but what the hell. As Bruce guzzles his drink...

dialogues.speaker: MILLS
dialogues.text: Why not. It’s special occasion.

dialogues.speaker: BRUCE
dialogues.text: Yeah. The night I finally fire your polyester ass.

dialogues.speaker: MILLS
dialogues.text: Brucie! Why all the hostility?

dialogues.speaker: BRUCE
dialogues.text: I’m just getting warmed up. And don’t give me that innocent look! I’ve just spent six days of my life making a sequel to one of the worst movies ever made!

dialogues.speaker: MILLS
dialogues.text: You’ve made worse. (that didn’t help!) Come on. The customer reviews on Amazon were great!

dialogues.speaker: BRUCE
dialogues.text: The ones I posted! Bruce polishes off his drink, wincing at the burn, as Mills motions for him to sit.

dialogues.speaker: MILLS
dialogues.text: Park it, B.C., unload. That’s why I’m here.

dialogues.speaker: BRUCE
dialogues.text: It’s just... I feel like I’m losing my muse. Mills blinks, an “oh God, not this again” expression.

dialogues.speaker: MILLS
dialogues.text: Say what?

dialogues.speaker: BRUCE
dialogues.text: The innocent, child-like quality all great artists tap to “create”... (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Verheiden "My Name Is Bruce" 4/2/06 18.

dialogues.speaker: CONTINUED
dialogues.text: While Bruce pontificates, Mills wearily motions for another drink, spreading his fingers to indicate he’d like a double.

dialogues.speaker: BRUCE, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: They say an actor’s life is like a painting, a work in progress, but how can I create my masterpiece when my paint’s drying up, my canvas is cracked and my brushes are coated in fake monster blood. Mills brings back his game face as Bruce finishes.

dialogues.speaker: MILLS
dialogues.text: It’s Deborah, isn’t it?

dialogues.speaker: BRUCE
dialogues.text: No.

dialogues.speaker: MILLS
dialogues.text: It’s been almost a year since your divorce.

dialogues.speaker: BRUCE
dialogues.text: I said no.

dialogues.speaker: MILLS
dialogues.text: You need to put her out of your mind.

dialogues.speaker: BRUCE
dialogues.text: If I say “no” three times will the Candyman come out?! (slides back) Screw this. You were fired when I walked in and you’re twice as fired now... As Bruce slides back, getting ready to leave...

dialogues.speaker: MILLS
dialogues.text: Leave now, you’ll never know what I got you for your birthday. The moment of actual sentiment catches Bruce off guard.

dialogues.speaker: BRUCE
dialogues.text: My birthday? You actually remembered?

dialogues.speaker: MILLS
dialogues.text: How could I forget? You're my numero uno client! (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Verheiden "My Name Is Bruce" 4/2/06 19.

dialogues.speaker: BRUCE
dialogues.text: If this is another Matthew Perry movie...

dialogues.speaker: MILLS
dialogues.text: Better.

dialogues.speaker: BRUCE
dialogues.text: Give me a hint.

dialogues.speaker: MILLS
dialogues.text: I thought you were firing me.

dialogues.speaker: BRUCE
dialogues.text: Goddamn it, Mills!

dialogues.speaker: MILLS
dialogues.text: Let’s just say it’s going to be the best birthday you’ve ever had. (snapping fingers) Garcon! Bring Mr. Campbell another highball! And pretzels all around! Tonight we celebrate! OFF Bruce sorely tempted, easily suckered by Mills’ offer of a snazzy birthday present...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Mills and Bruce exit together, Bruce three-sheets drunk and stumbling while Mills continues to console him.

dialogues.speaker: BRUCE
dialogues.text: (slurring) Happy birthday... to me... happy birthday... to muhhhh... Bruce grabs Mill’s face with both hands, squeezing it.

dialogues.speaker: BRUCE, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: I wuv you, man.

dialogues.speaker: MILLS
dialogues.text: (“I know you do.”) Uh ow ah ou. Bruce releases Mills as Mills’ Porsche Boxster comes up. (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Verheiden "My Name Is Bruce" 4/2/06 20.

dialogues.speaker: MILLS, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Enjoy what you’ve got, Bruce. You know how many wannabe Oliviers would quick-lime their Grandmothers for a career like yours? Sloppy drunk and emotional, Bruce lunges at Mills again, trying to squeeze his face.

dialogues.speaker: BRUCE
dialogues.text: Would ‘ou be my Grandmama?

dialogues.speaker: MILLS
dialogues.text: No. But thanks for the offer. Mills manages to duck him this time and duck into his car. As Mills pulls out, Bruce motions to the valet, who trots off to get Bruce’s car.

dialogues.speaker: BRUCE
dialogues.text: Maybe he’s right. Hell, I ama lucky fella. I’ve got my health... (racking cough) ...JE-sus... my divorce is almost final... (getting angry) ...lousy whore... (revving up) ...and I’ve got my fans... my loyal fans... who hated my last movie... hated my last five movies... me and my wonderful, wonderful FANS... As if on unfortunate cue, Bruce hears a “clop THUD clop THUD” as the limping fan he ran down at the studio hobbles toward him.

dialogues.speaker: DEVOTED FAN
dialogues.text: Mr. Campbell, Mr. Campbe...

dialogues.speaker: BRUCE
dialogues.text: Lucky friggin’ ME!! WUMP! Bruce throws a punch into the limping fan’s gut. Stunned, the fan drops to his knees, holding out the autographed photo he got earlier from Bruce as... BRUCE’S PINTO pulls up, the Valet screeching it to a halt in a haze of exhaust. The Valet steps out, holding out his hand for a tip, and Bruce plucks the photo from the gasping fan’s hand and passes it to the Valet. (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Verheiden "My Name Is Bruce" 4/2/06 21.

dialogues.speaker: BRUCE, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Merry Christmas. As Bruce roars off, swerving into the street, the gasping Devoted Fan grabs to get back his photo.

dialogues.speaker: DEVOTED FAN
dialogues.text: Give it back! That’s mine! The fan and the Valet get into a pitched fight over the glossy as the Pinto roars off into the distance...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A POLICE CAR is driving down a lonely stretch of road.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Uniformed Officer KELBO behind the wheel. 30ish, moustache, typical small town cop. As he drives, we can hear POLICE CALLS over the radio.

dialogues.speaker: DISPATCHER, (RADIO)
dialogues.text: Kelbo, this is dispatch. We’re getting calls about weird noises in the woods off Crescent, over. COP’S VOICE (RADIO) Roger that. I’m coming up on Crescent now, over. As Kelbo hangs up the microphone, suddenly

dialogues.speaker: A BIRD HITS THE WINDSHIELD OF HIS CAR
dialogues.text: Startled, Kelbo hits the brakes and goes into a sideways skid, stopping by the side of the road. He’s in the middle of nowhere, surrounded by woods.

dialogues.speaker: KELBO
dialogues.text: Damn. Kelbo steps out of the car to check the damage. The impact has spider-webbed the windshield and left spatters of blood on the white hood. Disgusted, Kelbo starts wiping up the blood on the hood. But as he cleans a patch, suddenly MORE BLOOD APPEARS. Then blood drips on his hand. With dawning apprehension, Kelbo realizes the blood is dripping down from above. He slowly turns, looking up... (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Verheiden "My Name Is Bruce" 4/2/06 22.

dialogues.speaker: CONTINUED
dialogues.text: INTO THE SHADOWED FACE OF THE CHINESE DEMON! There’s a silvery GLINT. A blade SLASHES forward. OFF Kelbo’s aborted SCREAM... EXT. BRUCE’S HOUSE - NIGHT The Pinto winds down a scrubby driveway and pulls up toa dilapidated

dialogues.speaker: TRAILER HOUSE
dialogues.text: in the middle of nowhere, banging over a row of garbage cans. Still drunk, Bruce gets out, grabbing a grubby suitcase from the back of the car. He stagger-walks to the door, walking over a mess of gathering mail, mostly magazines like HUSTLER, JUGGS, 40 D-CUPPER... INT. BRUCE’S HOUSE - NIGHT Cradling the magazines and mail in his arms, Bruce pushes the door open and enters, tossing the mail on a couch. We HEAR the tinkle-bell of a dog collar and little feet rustling as Bruce’s arrival arouses his dog.

dialogues.speaker: BRUCE
dialogues.text: Here boy. Come’mere, Sam’nRob. The little dog enters the front room, stops at Bruce’s feet and GROWLS MENACINGLY.

dialogues.speaker: BRUCE, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Whatsamatter boy? Whatsamatter with poor widdle Sam’nRob? The little dog continues to SNARL until Bruce remembers something. He pulls a brown paper bag from his jacket pocket and pulls out a pint of cheap bourbon. He unscrews the top and pours it into a doggie bowl.

dialogues.speaker: BRUCE, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Thought I forgot, didn’t you? As “Sammy” starts to drink greedily from the bowl, Bruce idly checks some of the “envelope” mail. Virtually every letter has red ink on it and says something about “FINAL NOTICE” or “THIRD REMINDER.” He tosses the mail and plops down in front of his ancient BLACK AND WHITE TELEVISION, replete with coat-hanger rabbit ears. Using a primitive remote, he switches the set on and gets a static ridden image of an “Entertainment Tonight” type announcer on a studio set.  Verheiden "My Name Is Bruce" 4/2/06 23.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (Still in Bruce’s B/W) The ANNOUNCER WOMAN is finishing a typical ET/Access Hollywood type story...

dialogues.speaker: ANNOUNCER
dialogues.text: ...studio sources say Tom Hanks’ next project will be released next Summer...

dialogues.speaker: BRUCE
dialogues.text: (mocking voice) Duh duh, “Bubba Gump,” yup yup yup...

dialogues.speaker: ANNOUNCER
dialogues.text: Next, we take a scarrrry look at the life and times of B-movie horror star Bruce Campbell... IN BRUCE'S LIVING ROOM, the thought of a actual publicity gives Bruce a smile. He tips up his bourbon bottle, toasting the screen.

dialogues.speaker: BRUCE
dialogues.text: Now we’re cookin’! A Photo of a smiling Bruce appears on screen, followed by the chironed letters: WHERE ARE THEY NOW?

dialogues.speaker: ANNOUNCER
dialogues.text: Campbell, best known for his roles in the horrific Evil Dead films, appears to have disappeared from the entertainment scene... Stunned, Bruce SPITS out a spew of bourbon.

dialogues.speaker: BRUCE
dialogues.text: Huh?!

dialogues.speaker: ANNOUNCER
dialogues.text: Tonight, our “Where Are They Now” reporter Charlie Payne takes an affectionate look back on a promising career that many feel was squandered on low budget trash... Bruce drains his pint and PITCHES the empty bottle at the TV, hitting the off-button. (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Verheiden "My Name Is Bruce" 4/2/06 24.

dialogues.speaker: BRUCE
dialogues.text: Those BASTARDS!! Staggering, enraged, Bruce goes to a cupboard and rummages through a half dozen empty whiskey bottles. There isn’t another drop in the house.

dialogues.speaker: BRUCE, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: They’re making me sound like a has- been! Like I’m all washed up... Desperate for more booze, Bruce notices “SamNRob” still lapping at the bourbon Bruce poured into his bowl. Bruce suddenly drops to his knees and grabs the bowl away from the snarling dog.

dialogues.speaker: BRUCE, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: They’re making me look pathetic! Bruce tips up the filthy doggie bowl and gulps down the rest of the bourbon, booze spilling down his shirt, enraged at his depiction on the show. OFF this moment... INT. DEBORAH’S HOUSE - BEDROOM - NIGHT Bruce’s ex-wife DEBORAH, 30's and attractive, is rolling over in bed, fumbling sleepily with the phone. The light up clock next to her bed says 3:14 AM.

dialogues.speaker: DEBORAH
dialogues.text: Oh God...

dialogues.speaker: WITH
dialogues.text: INT. BRUCE’S HOUSE - BEDROOM - NIGHT Bruce’s on his bed, hair sticking out wildly, tanked, phone cradled against his shoulder.

dialogues.speaker: BRUCE
dialogues.text: Hey, Deb. It’s me.

dialogues.speaker: DEBORAH
dialogues.text: What now, Bruce?

dialogues.speaker: BRUCE
dialogues.text: I was just, you know, celebrating the almost-wrap of my latest picture... just one more day... Bruce’s dog GROWLS LOUDLY off camera. (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Verheiden "My Name Is Bruce" 4/2/06 25.

dialogues.speaker: DEBORAH
dialogues.text: You got into the dog’s bowl again.

dialogues.speaker: BRUCE
dialogues.text: (yelling at dog) QUIET! Selfish mutt...

dialogues.speaker: DEBORAH
dialogues.text: It’s your birthday, isn’t it? Every year, it’s the same old “poor me” routine.

dialogues.speaker: BRUCE
dialogues.text: Can’t a guy get bombed and call his ex-wife at 3:00 in the morning without it “meaning” something?

dialogues.speaker: DEBORAH
dialogues.text: Bruce, I talked to Mills.

dialogues.speaker: BRUCE
dialogues.text: Yeah? What did ol’ ten percent have to say?

dialogues.speaker: DEBORAH
dialogues.text: Just that you were depressed. So he’s planning something special for your birthday.

dialogues.speaker: BRUCE
dialogues.text: (perks up) Did he say what?

dialogues.speaker: DEBORAH
dialogues.text: It’s a surprise!

dialogues.speaker: BRUCE
dialogues.text: Come on...

dialogues.speaker: DEBORAH
dialogues.text: Bruce...

dialogues.speaker: BRUCE
dialogues.text: (annoying baby-talk) Pweese pweese pweese Debwah...

dialogues.speaker: DEBORAH
dialogues.text: I’m hanging up... Bruce’s face falls.

dialogues.speaker: BRUCE
dialogues.text: No, don’t. I’m sorry, baby. (sniffling) (MORE ) (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Verheiden "My Name Is Bruce" 4/2/06 26.

dialogues.speaker: BRUCE, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: How did things get so messed up between us?

dialogues.speaker: DEBORAH
dialogues.text: You slept with the dog sitter.

dialogues.speaker: BRUCE
dialogues.text: One stupid mistake...

dialogues.speaker: DEBORAH
dialogues.text: All of them.

dialogues.speaker: BRUCE
dialogues.text: Twelve stupid mistakes. I was mixed up, crazy... God, I miss you and the kids...

dialogues.speaker: DEBORAH
dialogues.text: What kids?

dialogues.speaker: BRUCE
dialogues.text: The ones we would have had, if we'd just held on... Deborah takes a breath.

dialogues.speaker: DEBORAH
dialogues.text: You want the truth about us, Bruce? It wasn’t the cheating or the boozing or the endless whining that killed our marriage. You just couldn’t commit. To our relationship, your career, to much of anything... (getting mean) Go ahead. Name one single thing you stuck through to the end. Drunk, Bruce has to think a second, then finally:

dialogues.speaker: BRUCE
dialogues.text: Dogs always had a sitter... SLAM *CLICK* buzzzzz. Bruce just sits there, mulling drunkenly over his life of missed opportunities... IN DEBORAH'S BEDROOM, Deborah hangs up the phone and rolls over, revealing MILLS, Bruce’s agent, lying in bed beside her.

dialogues.speaker: MILLS
dialogues.text: Gimme some sugar, baby. As Deborah GIGGLES and they kiss...  Verheiden "My Name Is Bruce" 4/2/06 27. INT. BRUCE’S HOUSE - FRONT ROOM - NIGHT THUD THUD THUD. Someone’s banging on the trailer house door. Bruce, hair sticking out, face pale, looking like a walking hangover, stumbles toward the door.

dialogues.speaker: BRUCE
dialogues.text: Keep your pants on fer Chrissakes, it’s four in the friggin’ mornin’... Bruce throws open the door and... nobody’s there.

dialogues.speaker: BRUCE, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Ho ho. Very funny. He stands there a second, bleary and blinking, then notices something glistening at his feet. Curious, he bends down and reaches for a SHINY NEW QUARTER.

dialogues.speaker: BRUCE, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Saaayyyy. A brand new quar-- Suddenly a metal baseball bat swings down and CRACKS HIM across the back of the head. As Bruce drops, CUT TO BLACK.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: As an engine rumbles, Bruce, jammed in the trunk, wakes up. Dazed, he lifts his head and CRACKS it against the trunk lid. Cramped, barely able to move, he slowly realizes where he is.

dialogues.speaker: BRUCE
dialogues.text: What the hell -- ? He pushes against the trunk lid, trying to force it open. No good. Annoyed, he starts to YELL.

dialogues.speaker: BRUCE, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Hey! HEY!!! Lemme out of here! The car hits a hard BUMP, jarring Bruce, as JEFF’S MUFFLED VOICE calls back.

dialogues.speaker: JEFF, (0.S.)
dialogues.text: Mr. Campbell? Are you okay? (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Verheiden "My Name Is Bruce" 4/2/06 28.

dialogues.speaker: BRUCE
dialogues.text: Who are you? Who hit me?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Jeff is behind the wheel, driving down a dark highway.

dialogues.speaker: JEFF
dialogues.text: Uhh, that would be me. Sorry!

dialogues.speaker: BRUCE
dialogues.text: (sarcastic) Oh. Well. As long as you’re sorry...

dialogues.speaker: JEFF
dialogues.text: Really? They hit another bump, slamming Bruce up against the trunk lid.

dialogues.speaker: OWW
dialogues.text: (kicking at lid) Let me out of here, you psycho freak!

dialogues.speaker: JEFF
dialogues.text: I can’t. Not until we get to town. (helpful) I put some Twinkies and a couple magazines in the side pocket. And there’s a flashlight next to the spare. Disgruntled but not really knowing what else to do, Bruce finds the flashlight and switches it on. Near his head he finds a couple issues of FANGORIA and RUE MORGUE. As Bruce stares at the mags in disbelief...

dialogues.speaker: BRUCE
dialogues.text: No no no...

dialogues.speaker: JEFF
dialogues.text: I know you’re probably sore and tired and suffering from a concussion, but... is it true you’re doing a sequel to Cavealien? (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Verheiden "My Name Is Bruce" 4/2/06 29.

dialogues.speaker: BRUCE
dialogues.text: What?!

dialogues.speaker: JEFF
dialogues.text: That’s probably my favorite movie of all time!

dialogues.speaker: BRUCE
dialogues.text: Oh my God. He’s a fan. (screaming)

dialogues.speaker: HELP
dialogues.text: BAM! Another bump slams Bruce’s head again.

dialogues.speaker: BRUCE, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: GAWW! For God's sake, could you at least go easy on the bumps?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: As Jeff's car speeds down the road, reveal a sign: “ROUGH ROAD NEXT 75 MILES.” As the car bumps along...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A FARMER steps out his front door with a shotgun, looking off his porch into the darkness. His WIFE stands behind him, anxious.

dialogues.speaker: WIFE
dialogues.text: What is it, Hank?

dialogues.speaker: HANK
dialogues.text: I don’t know. Thought I heard something in the barn. Serious, he PUMPS his shotgun.

dialogues.speaker: HANK, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Stay inside. Bolt the door. Don’t open it, no matter what you hear! Scared, the wife closes the door.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Her back against the door, the Wife listens as Hank’s footsteps crunch off toward the barn. A barn door CREAKS open. The footsteps enter, fading away. (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Verheiden "My Name Is Bruce" 4/2/06 30.

dialogues.speaker: CONTINUED
dialogues.text: Then suddenly there are MULTIPLE GUNSHOTS! The Wife GASPS, shocked.

dialogues.speaker: WIFE
dialogues.text: Oh dear Lord... She hears frantic running, then something SLAMS against the door. POUNDS AGAINST THE WOOD.

dialogues.speaker: HANK, (0.S.)
dialogues.text: Open the door! Open the door!! For Christ’s sake, OPEN THE DOOR! Terrified, the Wife throws open the door... only to find her husband Hank standing there, LAUGHING. It was a sick practical joke.

dialogues.speaker: HANK, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Haw haw haw!!

dialogues.speaker: WIFE
dialogues.text: You bastard! I can’t believe you punked me like that!

dialogues.speaker: HANK
dialogues.text: You should have seen your face! Told you to never open the do-- Suddenly a SAMURAI BLADE erupts through Hank’s chest. He looks down, gasping in shock, blood spilling from the wound... the eerie silhouette of THE CHINESE DEMON visible behind him. OFF this...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The “Welcome To Sawville” sign, still dripping with (dried and yucky) egg yolk. A hand reaches in and changes the population number “2649” into “2646” with a quick stroke of paint...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Bruce is lying, cramped and half asleep, when the trunk lid suddenly flies open and he’s doused in bright sunshine. Wincing in the light, a sticky Twinkie wrapper stuck to his cheek, Bruce JUMPS UP and suddenly FREEZES.

dialogues.speaker: BRUCE
dialogues.text: Uhhhh...  Verheiden "My Name Is Bruce" 4/2/06 31.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: PULL BACK to reveal Jeff's car surrounded by two dozen Sawville townfolk, all rural types, who let out a semi- rousing CHEER as Bruce staggers out of the trunk.

dialogues.speaker: TOWNSFOLK
dialogues.text: Hip hip hooray! Hip hip hooray!

dialogues.speaker: BRUCE
dialogues.text: What th -- The bearded MAYOR of Sawville steps forward, authoritative, offering his hand to a bewildered Bruce.

dialogues.speaker: MAYOR
dialogues.text: Welcome to Sawville, Mr. Campbell!

dialogues.speaker: BRUCE
dialogues.text: “Sawville?” (peels off Twinkie wrapper) Where the fuck is “Sawville?” Jeff, wearing a CAVEALIEN tee-shirt, rushes around from the driver's side of the car, surprised by Bruce’s outburst. Trying to calm him.

dialogues.speaker: JEFF
dialogues.text: Easy, man. That’s the Mayor!

dialogues.speaker: BRUCE
dialogues.text: I don’t care if he’s the King of Kiss-My-Ass-ia! I just spent six hours in a TRUNK. I want some answers, chop chop! Bruce waits, looking out across the stunned/dull faces of the Townsfolk, momentarily locking eyes with KELLY, 30-ish and pretty. It’s a “love at first sight” moment for Bruce, complete with a slow motion “hair shake” from Kelly. He attempts a suave gesture, despite the “bed head” hairdo from his trunk ride.

dialogues.speaker: BRUCE, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Holy -- (recovering) Don’t worry, sweet-stuff. When I’m done with these yokels, I've got a pair of lips with your name on ‘em. (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Verheiden "My Name Is Bruce" 4/2/06 32.

dialogues.speaker: CONTINUED
dialogues.text: She holds Bruce’s look for a moment, almost like she’s going to respond, then she shakes her head again, this time in utter disdain.

dialogues.speaker: KELLY
dialogues.text: You've got to be kidding. As Kelly pulls away from the crowd. Bruce snaps back into “I’m pissed!” mode.

dialogues.speaker: BRUCE
dialogues.text: Well?! Don’t all talk at once! One of the Townfolk tries another desultory cheer.

dialogues.speaker: TOWN GUY
dialogues.text: Hip hip... (no one is helping) Uhh...

dialogues.speaker: BRUCE
dialogues.text: Maybe you don’t get “moving pichters” in this fart-hole, so let me explain something. I’ma “movie star.” Tinseltown. Lights, camera, etc.? When Bruce Campbell says frog, production assistants jump! (leaning into it) I even know Sam Raimi! There’s a muffled, awed “ooooh” from the crowd.

dialogues.speaker: BRUCE, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: So when you kidnapped me, you didn’t just commit a crime against me... this is a crime against art! (looks at watch) In fact, I was due on set three hours ago. You can bet they’1ll pull out the stops to get me back! To amplify this point, we suddenly CUT TO:

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The myopic Director peers through his coke bottle glasses, setting up what looks like the tenth scene of the day, his cameraman nearby. (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Verheiden "My Name Is Bruce" 4/2/06 33.

dialogues.speaker: CONTINUED
dialogues.text: ON SET, Petra, her uniform unzipped to reveal considerable cleavage, is in the clutches of the Cavealien creature, which looks remarkably not- frightening from this angle.

dialogues.speaker: DIRECTOR
dialogues.text: Okay, looks good... (squinting) Wait a second. What are those bulges on his chest? D.P. Breasts. That’s Petra.

dialogues.speaker: DIRECTOR
dialogues.text: (squints again) Thought it was Bruce. D.P. A-hole didn’t show up. Bob from the machine shop is going to play him for the rest of the shoot. The D.P. hooks a thumb toward a guy who looks nothing like Bruce, but is wearing Bruce’s space uniform while covering the bottom half of his face with a cape, like Dracula. (This is a direct homage to PLAN NINE FROM OUTER SPACE, where the awful double for a dead Bela Lugosi covered his face with a cape.) The Director considers a moment, then shrugs.

dialogues.speaker: DIRECTOR
dialogues.text: Oh. Okay. (to Petra) Action!!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: CUT BACK to Bruce exactly where we left him before the cutaway, still checking his watch.

dialogues.speaker: BRUCE
dialogues.text: So as much as I’d love to stick around until the FBI rips you grit- eaters a new one...

dialogues.speaker: JEFF
dialogues.text: But your agent said you were “between jobs.” Bruce shakes his head in disbelief. (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Verheiden "My Name Is Bruce" 4/2/06 34.

dialogues.speaker: BRUCE
dialogues.text: You called my agent?

dialogues.speaker: JEFF
dialogues.text: He was very helpful.

dialogues.speaker: BRUCE
dialogues.text: That couldn’t have been Toddner... Bruce stops. Dawning realization washing over him.

dialogues.speaker: BRUCE, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Wait a minute. What else did he say?

dialogues.speaker: JEFF
dialogues.text: Just something about not booking you on your birthday...

dialogues.speaker: BRUCE
dialogues.text: Birthday...? Birthday...? Say... As this sinks in, a light comes on for Bruce. His birthday? He suddenly looks at the Mayor and Townfolk through new eyes.

dialogues.speaker: BRUCE, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Mills, you magnificent bastard. When you said you had a “surprise” in store... More blank looks. They have no idea what Bruce is talking about.

dialogues.speaker: MAYOR
dialogues.text: Mr. Campbell, I realize this is rather... unorthodox, but Jeffrey tells us your skills extend beyond the Thespian... (dramatic beat) And the town of Sawville desperately needs your help. Bruce sees the Mayor through new eyes, assessing his performance.

dialogues.speaker: BRUCE
dialogues.text: That’s good. You're good.

dialogues.speaker: MAYOR
dialogues.text: (perplexed) Thank you...? (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Verheiden "My Name Is Bruce" 4/2/06 35.

dialogues.speaker: CONTINUED
dialogues.text: Bruce considers a moment, rubbing his aching head, then makes a decision.

dialogues.speaker: BRUCE
dialogues.text: Let’s say I decide to play along. What’s next?

dialogues.speaker: MAYOR
dialogues.text: Well, uhh, we’ve arranged a presentation at City Hall. Rejuvenated, Bruce glances over the heads of the Townsfolk and notices cute Kelly entering an official looking building.

dialogues.speaker: BRUCE
dialogues.text: (re: Kelly) Is that where Miss Make-My-Day is headed?

dialogues.speaker: MAYOR
dialogues.text: As a matter of fact... Bruce smiles, definitely getting into the “ruse.”

dialogues.speaker: BRUCE
dialogues.text: Lead the way, gents!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The Mayor, Jeff and the other Townfolk gather in the town’s small “town hall”, outfitted with benches and a slide projector in the middle of the chairs. As Bruce enters, he makes a point of looking for KELLY. She’s sitting between two FARMERS, but Bruce doesn’t care. He pushes down the crowded row...

dialogues.speaker: FARMER FARMER
dialogues.text: Ow... my foot! Aghh, my corns!

dialogues.speaker: BRUCE
dialogues.text: (to farmer by Kelly) Yo, Jimmy Dean. You’re in my seat. The Farmer scoots down and Bruce squeezes in next to Kelly. The slide projector is right behind Bruce’s shoulder. Kelly shoots Bruce a cold look but holds her tongue. (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Verheiden "My Name Is Bruce" 4/2/06 36.

dialogues.speaker: BRUCE, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: (whispering) You're probably can’t break character, but I gotta tell you, you guys really had me going.

dialogues.speaker: KELLY
dialogues.text: What?

dialogues.speaker: BRUCE
dialogues.text: For a second I thought I was ina remake of “Deliverance” and somebody was about to tell me to go “soo-eeey!” As Kelly reacts poorly to the slur, the oblivious Bruce offers his hand.

dialogues.speaker: BRUCE, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Sorry, I should have introduced myself. I’m Bruce. Bruce Campbell. Kelly unenthusiastically shakes Bruce’s hand.

dialogues.speaker: KELLY
dialogues.text: Kelly Graham.

dialogues.speaker: BRUCE
dialogues.text: Graham. Bet all the boys go “crackers” over you.

dialogues.speaker: KELLY
dialogues.text: (not amused) Ha ha ha.

dialogues.speaker: BRUCE
dialogues.text: Me, I could have sworn your name was Daisy.

dialogues.speaker: KELLY
dialogues.text: Why?

dialogues.speaker: BRUCE
dialogues.text: Because I have this crazy urge to “plant” one on you. Aghast, Kelly starts to get up.

dialogues.speaker: KELLY
dialogues.text: I have to go... But as Kelly rises, the Mayor and Jeff motion for her to stay put. They don’t want to rile Bruce back up. (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Verheiden "My Name Is Bruce" 4/2/06 37.

dialogues.speaker: CONTINUED
dialogues.text: As she reluctantly sits back down, more people enter and take seats. The Mayor goes to the front of the room, standing next to a projector screen.

dialogues.speaker: MAYOR
dialogues.text: Mr. Campbell, if you’re ready?

dialogues.speaker: BRUCE
dialogues.text: Knock yourself out, Whiskers. As the lights dim, Bruce lounges back, elbows on the back of his chair, a cocky look, like he loves being the center of attention...

dialogues.speaker: MAYOR
dialogues.text: As we all know, Sawville was mining country before the logging industry moved in... FIRST SLIDE: A shot of an old mine entrance.

dialogues.speaker: MAYOR, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: In the late 1860's, hundreds of Chinese immigrants came to our shores to help work the claims. SECOND SLIDE: Photo of a modern Chinese Restaurant. While the slides continue, Bruce continues his line of patter with poor Kelly.

dialogues.speaker: BRUCE
dialogues.text: Kelly’s an Irish name, isn’t it? (bad Irish accent) Maybe later you can show me your “Lucky Charms.” As Kelly squirms at Bruce’s attempts to “charm” her...

dialogues.speaker: MAYOR
dialogues.text: The largest mine was the Triple T., run with an iron fist by the legendary Thomas T. Tripletee. THIRD SLIDE: A photo of a harsh looking man with a handlebar moustache. Dressed in 1860-style finery.

dialogues.speaker: MAYOR, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: At her height, the Triple T employed hundreds of Chinese immigrant laborers. They worked long hours, in harsh and primitive conditions, surviving on rice and bean curd... (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Verheiden "My Name Is Bruce" 4/2/06 38.

dialogues.speaker: CONTINUED
dialogues.text: FOURTH SLIDE: A historical photo of overworked Chinese laborers standing in front of a primitive mine. They look bedraggled and skinny. Bruce nudges Kelly.

dialogues.speaker: BRUCE
dialogues.text: You want primitive, you should have seen craft services on my last picture! Licorice sticks were like tent stakes! Kelly glares at Bruce, incredulous.

dialogues.speaker: MAYOR
dialogues.text: Then disaster struck. A cave-in. Over a hundred Chinese workers were buried alive. Sawville was devastated... FOURTH SLIDE: Photo of the front page of the local paper, “The Sawville Gazette”, circa 1860. The big headline reads: CAVE IN CLOSES TRIPLE T. Next headline: FOREMAN SUFFERS BROKEN LEG. Next headline (smallest): CALL GOES OUT, SEND MORE CHINESE.

dialogues.speaker: MAYOR, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Soon after, rumors began to spread of a curse. FIFTH SLIDE: A colorful image of the “Guan-Di” warrior, a mythical Samurai with flowing robes, glowing red eyes and a deadly sword.

dialogues.speaker: MAYOR, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Legend has it that a Chinese demon was summoned to protect the spirits of all those who died. SIXTH SLIDE: A shadowy, out of focus image of the Chinese Demon, barely visible but pretty damn creepy.

dialogues.speaker: MAYOR, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: An amateur photographer captured this image almost fifty years ago, when the demon was last thought active... in fact this is the only copy of that rare photo...

dialogues.speaker: BRUCE
dialogues.text: (blowing it off) Yeah, yeah, real scary. (to Kelly) Look, baby, when this is over, how about you and me sharing a bottle of Chateau La Partydown? (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Verheiden "My Name Is Bruce" 4/2/06 39.

dialogues.speaker: KELLY
dialogues.text: I barely know you!

dialogues.speaker: BRUCE
dialogues.text: Couple glasses of Sawville’s finest and we’ll be the best of friends. I may not be Fred Flintstone, but trust me, I can still make your “bed rock”... Kelly suddenly explodes.

dialogues.speaker: KELLY
dialogues.text: That’s it! You are, without a doubt, the rudest, crudest, most insincere jackass I’ve ever met! As she stands, Bruce also rises, his arm bumping the slide projector and jamming the lens against the hot bulb. As the precious demon image MELTS AND BURNS...

dialogues.speaker: BRUCE
dialogues.text: Crude?! (loud, to room) What crawled up her crack and died? As Kelly tries to get down the row, the Mayor desperately tries to salvage the situation.

dialogues.speaker: MAYOR
dialogues.text: We need a champion, Mr. Campbell. A warrior who understands these dark forces. Bruce glances over his shoulder, looks over the group.

dialogues.speaker: BRUCE
dialogues.text: Great. Want me to pick somebody?

dialogues.speaker: MAYOR
dialogues.text: Actually, Jeff told us that you had some... experience with evil spirits.

dialogues.speaker: BRUCE
dialogues.text: Moi? Gents, you got me all wr... Suddenly there’s the hideous SCREECH of FINGERNAILS on a blackboard, followed by a wizened CACKLE from the back of the room. All eyes turn toward the rear of the hall and (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Verheiden "My Name Is Bruce" 4/2/06 40.

dialogues.speaker: CONTINUED
dialogues.text: WING, a small, elderly Chinese man with a wispy goatee, wearing traditional Chinese robes. He has brought a small portable chalkboard just to make the screech noise.

dialogues.speaker: WING
dialogues.text: Be warned. He who confronts the Guan-Di confronts death itself. Bruce slips down the aisle and walks back to Wing.

dialogues.speaker: BRUCE
dialogues.text: Hello, second act escalation. (to Mayor) What’s with the fortune cookie?

dialogues.speaker: MAYOR
dialogues.text: His name is Wing. The last living descendant of the dead laborers. For punctuation, Wing scratches his nails across the blackboard again. Bruce winces and grabs the blackboard away from him, tosses it aside.

dialogues.speaker: BRUCE
dialogues.text: “Jaws.” We get it.

dialogues.speaker: WING
dialogues.text: The Guan-Di has been unleashed from his resting place. As Wing says this, he looks straight Jeff, who winces guiltily. Bruce, meanwhile, misunderstands “Guan-Di” for “Gandhi.”

dialogues.speaker: BRUCE
dialogues.text: Always figured this “Gandhi” fella for being some sorta pushover in a diaper...

dialogues.speaker: WING
dialogues.text: The Guan-Di is a great warrior. Protector of the dead, savior of the innocent and of bean curd...

dialogues.speaker: BRUCE
dialogues.text: Bean curd?

dialogues.speaker: WING
dialogues.text: It’s a Chinese thing. (intense) The graves of the dead were disturbed and the Guan-Di will not rest until this sacrilege has been avenged. (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Verheiden "My Name Is Bruce" 4/2/06 41.

dialogues.speaker: BRUCE
dialogues.text: And when exactly will that happen?

dialogues.speaker: WING
dialogues.text: When every blood relative of the one responsible lies rotting in the Earth. Oddly, Bruce brightens at that.

dialogues.speaker: BRUCE
dialogues.text: Well hell. There can’t be that many. (looks across room) Blood relatives, raise your hands. Virtually every hand in the City Hall goes up.

dialogues.speaker: BRUCE, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Remind me to lock my door tonight.

dialogues.speaker: WING
dialogues.text: (points at Bruce) He will continue to kill, and with each death his strength will increase. Anyone who tries to interfere... will die... A light bulb suddenly EXPLODES overhead, sending a shower of sparks down on the frightened crowd. Everyone turns, including Bruce. Then someone looks back toward Wing and GASPS.

dialogues.speaker: TOWN GUY TOWN GUY 2
dialogues.text: Wing’s gone! He’s gone! Bruce turns and sure enough, Wing has disappeared. As the Townsfolk murmur uneasily, Bruce looks out the window...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Bruce sees Wing walking nonchalantly down the sidewalk, clutching a bowling ball bag.

dialogues.speaker: BRUCE
dialogues.text: Uhh --

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Bruce is about to tell the people in the hall about his “Wing spotting” when the Mayor SHOUTS over the voices. (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Verheiden "My Name Is Bruce" 4/2/06 42.

dialogues.speaker: MAYOR
dialogues.text: Mr. Campbell, the future of Sawville rests in your hands. The place goes silent. Waiting for Bruce’s response. Bruce gauges them, then...

dialogues.speaker: BRUCE
dialogues.text: Lemme get this straight. One of your boys goes Giambi on my skull, locks me in a trunk and drags me to hayseed central... and now you expect me to lay my life on the line against some supernatural hell-spawn? The Mayor looks at the other townfolk, shrugs.

dialogues.speaker: MAYOR
dialogues.text: Ehh, more or less. Bruce looks across the desperate Townies. His face is arrogant until he spots Kelly, standing by the door, hesitating as she awaits his answer.

dialogues.speaker: BRUCE
dialogues.text: Lucky for you, I find myself at a crossroads in my life. Struggling to find the artist, the “hero” that I know still lies deep inside me. The faces go from desperate to blank. But everyone continues to listen.

dialogues.speaker: BRUCE, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Maybe that’s why I’m here, to rekindle that spirit. (revving himself up) It’s the ultimate acting challenge. “Method” times ten, a way to reclaim my dying muse...

dialogues.speaker: MAYOR
dialogues.text: Will you help us, Mr. Campbell? Bruce sucks in his gut, puffs out his chest and strikes a heroic pose.

dialogues.speaker: BRUCE
dialogues.text: Can. (pregnant pause) And will! (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Verheiden "My Name Is Bruce" 4/2/06 43.

dialogues.speaker: CONTINUED
dialogues.text: As CHEERS erupt from the grateful crowd and Bruce exults in their “love”... INT. JEFF’S CAR - DAY Bruce rides in the passenger seat as Jeff drives. Bruce is leaning back in the seat, waving like a Rose Parade Princess as they pass overjoyed pedestrians.

dialogues.speaker: BRUCE
dialogues.text: So you’re telling me the whole town’s in on this?

dialogues.speaker: JEFF
dialogues.text: (puzzled) Well, yeah.

dialogues.speaker: BRUCE
dialogues.text: Guess it’s like some crazy fund- raiser, huh? Instead of a bake- sale, you turn your town into Demonsville for a few weeks a year.

dialogues.speaker: JEFF
dialogues.text: No... I mean... (distraught) My friend Clayton was killed by this thing. I had to do something. Bruce nods knowingly, thinking Jeff’s still trying to stay in character.

dialogues.speaker: BRUCE
dialogues.text: That’s cool. Professional courtesy. No more questions. (looks out window) So what’s next, kid?

dialogues.speaker: JEFF
dialogues.text: Town’s throwing a party for you tonight. Sort of a send off before you head into battle. (tentative smile) Something I’d like to show you first. Jeff pulls off the road and turns up a driveway, driving past a house toward a TRAILER parked on a hill. As they approach, Bruce’s jaw drops open. The trailer is dead ringer for his Victorville digs. (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Verheiden "My Name Is Bruce" 4/2/06 44.

dialogues.speaker: BRUCE
dialogues.text: You gotta be shittin’ me. INT. JEFF’S TRAILER - DAY The door pushes in and Jeff ushers the perplexed but still game Bruce through the door. As they enter, the lights are off and the front room is in shadow. Jeff reaches for the light switch and clicks it on, and BRUCE STOPS IN HIS TRACKS. Jeff's trailer is a virtual shrine to all things Bruce Campbell. There are movie posters, scripts and 8 x 10 glossies... DVDs, videos and laserdiscs... scrapbooks of newspaper articles, trade ads, Bruce’s books, etc.

dialogues.speaker: BRUCE
dialogues.text: Kid, if your last name’s “Lector” I’m outta here... Jeff shrugs, self-conscious but still proud.

dialogues.speaker: JEFF
dialogues.text: Guess I am kind of a fan. Stunned, Bruce looks around the collection. There’s a demon mask from the first EVIL DEAD. A bottle of bug goo from ALIEN APOCALYPSE. A shoulder patch from the CAVEALIEN movie.

dialogues.speaker: BRUCE
dialogues.text: “Kinda?” Only thing missing is a stool sample! Bruce notices the Chinese Amulet that Jeff stole from the graveyard hanging from a Bruce action figure. Bruce grabs the amulet, checking it out.

dialogues.speaker: BRUCE, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: This doesn’t ring a bell... Jeff grabs it back, stuffing it in his pocket.

dialogues.speaker: JEFF
dialogues.text: That’s... personal. Oblivious, Bruce keeps looking, surprised to find a photo of him with his ex-wife Deborah tucked in with the other memorabilia. Touched by the old photo, which had been taken in happier times, Bruce takes it off the shelf.

dialogues.speaker: BRUCE
dialogues.text: Where did you get this? (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Verheiden "My Name Is Bruce" 4/2/06 45.

dialogues.speaker: JEFF
dialogues.text: Www. photos-of-bruce-campbell-with- his-ex-wife-deborah dot com. (watching Bruce) You... miss her, don’t you? Bruce stares at the photo.

dialogues.speaker: BRUCE
dialogues.text: Guess I do. But sometimes things happen between people that you just can’t take back.

dialogues.speaker: JEFF
dialogues.text: Like the dog-sitters? Bruce does a double-take.

dialogues.speaker: BRUCE
dialogues.text: How the hell --

dialogues.speaker: JEFF
dialogues.text: It was in Fangoria! (as Bruce recovers) Look, I know this was a huge imposition, Mr. Campbell, so whatever you need, just let me know. Bruce can’t help it. He’s starting to like this kid.

dialogues.speaker: BRUCE
dialogues.text: First of all, “Mr. Campbell” makes soup. You can call me Bruce. Bruce sniffs his arm pits, grimacing.

dialogues.speaker: BRUCE, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: And if you really wanna get on my good side, fetch me a bottle of Jack, a bar of soap, then point me toward the nearest motel with hot water and a naked cheerleaders channel.

dialogues.speaker: JEFF
dialogues.text: (thinking) Hmm. Closest motel is the Pink Lumberjack... Bruce tightens at that.

dialogues.speaker: BRUCE
dialogues.text: Keep going. (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Verheiden "My Name Is Bruce" 4/2/06 46.

dialogues.speaker: JEFF
dialogues.text: Then there’s the Manflower on Route 99, Ryan’s Rear-Entry on Old Prescott Road, and...

dialogues.speaker: BRUCE
dialogues.text: Maybe I’1l just spruce up here. Jeff is thrilled. A visit from his hero!

dialogues.speaker: JEFF
dialogues.text: Really? Wow! Great! I brought some fresh clothes from your trailer.

dialogues.speaker: BRUCE
dialogues.text: That’s wonderful, kid... Bruce is about to respond when he notices a shelf of hand labelled video tapes.

dialogues.speaker: BRUCE, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Jesus God. You actually have every episode of Jack Of All Trades?

dialogues.speaker: JEFF
dialogues.text: Yeah. Want to watch one? Bruce reluctantly tosses his jacket across the couch.

dialogues.speaker: BRUCE
dialogues.text: I’m gonna regret this. OFF Jeff's hero-worshipping smile...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The Chinese cemetery visible out front. Wing, the Chinese Man, moves through the old stones toward the foreboding cave site.

dialogues.speaker: WING
dialogues.text: (to “ancestors” ) They allowed you to die... left it to the few who survived to tend your spirits...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Wing goes up to the cave and sits at the entrance, the wind whistling eerily around him. (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Verheiden "My Name Is Bruce" 4/2/06 47.

dialogues.speaker: WING
dialogues.text: I pray to you, Guan-Di, for vengeance. I pray for you to destroy them all... (with intensity) Especially the demon-fighter known... as Campbell... INT. JEFF’S TRAILER - DAY Bruce steps out of the trailer’s bathroom, dressed in fresh clothes, still toweling his hair dry. Curious, Bruce holds out a small bottle with an “EVIL DEAD” logo but Japanese lettering identifying the actual product.

dialogues.speaker: BRUCE
dialogues.text: Ahh! Nothing like a shower to wash your blues away! (holding out bottle) Where the heck did you find this “Evil Dead” shampoo?

dialogues.speaker: JEFF
dialogues.text: That’s drain cleaner! Bruce stops drying his head, looking down as a big CLUMP of hair falls from the towel.

dialogues.speaker: BRUCE
dialogues.text: That would explain the burning sensation. Gingerly, Bruce tosses the towel aside, catching the worshipful look from Jeff.

dialogues.speaker: BRUCE, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: (off Jeff's look) What? Jeff realizes he’s been staring and looks away, a little embarrassed.

dialogues.speaker: JEFF
dialogues.text: It’s just... you’re going up against the Guan-Di tonight and you're not even scared. Bruce looks at Jeff, assuming this is part of his birthday present.

dialogues.speaker: BRUCE
dialogues.text: Compared to Kandarian devils, this Guan-Di cat’s no biggie-mo. (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Verheiden "My Name Is Bruce" 4/2/06 48.

dialogues.speaker: JEFF
dialogues.text: Really?

dialogues.speaker: BRUCE
dialogues.text: Look, kid, when you’re in the hero business, there are only two things you need to know. One, monsters are mostly pussies. Two, repeat number one.

dialogues.speaker: JEFF
dialogues.text: Wow. As Jeff reacts with awe, Bruce slaps his belly, “I’m hungry!” style.

dialogues.speaker: BRUCE
dialogues.text: Now, think a hungry demon slayer could score a few Slim-Jims, then catch a ride into town?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Jeff pulls up to the curb in his pick-up and Bruce slides out, finishing his peanut butter and jelly sandwich. Jeff nods down the street toward a bar and grill festooned with plastic flags and decorations.

dialogues.speaker: JEFF
dialogues.text: I promised to pick a few things up for the party. Sure you’ll be all right on your own? Bruce glances down the street of the one-horse town.

dialogues.speaker: BRUCE
dialogues.text: If I get lost, I’ll fire a flare. As Jeff nervously pulls away, Bruce saunters down the sidewalk, cocky as he nods and waves at passerby, playing the role of “town hero” to the hilt. Passing a GROCERY STORE with a display of apples out front, Bruce grabs an apple and polishes it on his sleeve. The SHOPKEEPER steps out, like he’s proud to have Bruce pausing at his store. Bruce takes a big, juicy bite.

dialogues.speaker: BRUCE, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Nice apple! Bruce raises an eyebrow, “thanks, pal” style, and continues down the sidewalk, pausing in front of an (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Verheiden "My Name Is Bruce" 4/2/06 49.

dialogues.speaker: CONTINUED
dialogues.text: APPLIANCE STORE. A display of ghetto blaster radios out front. As the APPLIANCE STORE OWNER watches, Bruce hefts one of the radios, cranking up the sound.

dialogues.speaker: BRUCE, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Nice radio! Assuming the radio is also “on the house”, Bruce just walks off with it, leaving the speechless Appliance Store Owner standing there, not sure how to react. A few yards down, Bruce walks past an ELDERLY MAN who gives Bruce the sign of the cross. Bruce gives the guy a slap across the back.

dialogues.speaker: BRUCE, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Nice improv! As Bruce continues on, a gaggle of excited SCHOOL CHILDREN suddenly rush up and surround him, “hail the conquering hero” style.

dialogues.speaker: KIDS
dialogues.text: Mr. Campbell! Bruce! Bruce! Bruce holds his arms out, savoring the adulation as he continues down the sidewalk.

dialogues.speaker: BRUCE
dialogues.text: What’s up, kids?

dialogues.speaker: FIRST KID
dialogues.text: Are... are you really going to save us from the monster?

dialogues.speaker: BRUCE
dialogues.text: That’s the idea, son. There’s a collective OOOOH from the youngsters. A SECOND KID shows Bruce a crude crayola drawing of a cartoon Bruce heroically stabbing a monster.

dialogues.speaker: SECOND KID
dialogues.text: I drew this picture of you!

dialogues.speaker: BRUCE
dialogues.text: Not bad, junior, not bad. A THIRD KID shows Bruce a crude crayola drawing of a cartoon Bruce getting his head torn off by a monster. Blood spurting from his gaping neck wound. (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Verheiden "My Name Is Bruce" 4/2/06 50.

dialogues.speaker: THIRD KID
dialogues.text: So did I! Bruce double-takes, shoving the drawing back at the kid.

dialogues.speaker: BRUCE
dialogues.text: Get with the program, Rembrandt. As the kids continue to crowd around him, Bruce finally arrives at... EXT. GREENE’S BAR - DAY A large banner across the front of the bar reads “HAIL OUR CHAMPION: BRUCE CAMBELL.” Bruce stops under the banner, taking a second to study it.

dialogues.speaker: BRUCE
dialogues.text: Memo to self, buy agent a dictionary. But before he can lament the poor spelling too long, he’s spotted by various TOWNFOLK who rush up and surround him. As Bruce exults in their adoration, the Townfolk lift him on their collective shoulders and carry him inside... CRACKING HIS HEAD on the door jamb. As he’s pulled inside, rubbing his sore noggin...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A small-town country dance-bar, with a wooden floor, tables, and a long bar across one wall. A WOMAN wearing an apron is behind the bar, back to us, as Bruce is lowered to the floor by the crowd. Bruce steps up to the bar like a movie cowboy, the Townfolk crowding around him...

dialogues.speaker: TOWNFOLK
dialogues.text: What do you want, Bruce? Open bar! It’s on the house! As the “waitress” bends over to grab a bottle, Bruce checks out her ass, nudging the guy next to him.

dialogues.speaker: BRUCE
dialogues.text: (re: her butt) Nothing like spending a night out on Half Moon Bay, ehh, boys? (to Woman behind bar) (MORE ) (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Verheiden "My Name Is Bruce" 4/2/06 51.

dialogues.speaker: BRUCE, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Hey, baby, how about a sloe comfortable screw up against the wall... As Bruce chortles at the old gag, the Woman turns, revealing she’s KELLY. Bruce chokes on his laughter as she glowers at him. BRUCE (CONT’D) (*gulp* ) -.-with a lime twist? Nonchalant, Kelly picks up a bowl of pretzels, offering them to Bruce.

dialogues.speaker: KELLY
dialogues.text: Pretzel?

dialogues.speaker: BRUCE
dialogues.text: (reaching to bowl) Don’t mind if I... Kelly suddenly THROWS the entire bowl into Bruce’s face. As Bruce recovers, Kelly starts making Bruce’s drink.

dialogues.speaker: BRUCE, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Look, I know what you’re thinking. Movie-star like yours truly might look down his schnoze at an every day waitress, but trust me, doll- face, that’s not how the Bruce-man operates. She’s almost done making the drink.

dialogues.speaker: KELLY
dialogues.text: I own this place.

dialogues.speaker: BRUCE
dialogues.text: (relieved) On the other hand, movie star like me doing a plain-vanilla waitress would be a definite step down... Kelly pick up the drink as if to pass it over, then laconically THROWS IT into Bruce’s face. The Townfolk GASP, but Bruce just accepts it.

dialogues.speaker: KELLY
dialogues.text: Want another? Bruce licks at the drink as it spills around his face. (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Verheiden "My Name Is Bruce" 4/2/06 52.

dialogues.speaker: BRUCE
dialogues.text: In a glass would be nice. (off her glare) Is it me, or did we get off on the wrong foot? In the background, Jeff enters, carrying some boxes.

dialogues.speaker: KELLY
dialogues.text: We never “got off” at all, and if there’s a God, we never will. (glances toward Jeff) Unfortunately, my son seems to think you’re some kind of hero. Bruce follows her eyes, realizes she’s looking at Jeff.

dialogues.speaker: BRUCE
dialogues.text: Ultra-fan belongs to you? Bruce takes Kelly’s hand, throwing an exaggerated look at her ring finger.

dialogues.speaker: BRUCE, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: I don’t see a wedding ring...

dialogues.speaker: KELLY
dialogues.text: That’s because Jeff's father left us. Right after Jeff was born.

dialogues.speaker: BRUCE
dialogues.text: Must have been hard, raising a boy on your own. (big smile) But in the “lemons into lemonade” category, sounds like there’s no reason you and I can’t do a little of the ol’ “trains and tunnels”... Kelly stares at Bruce, aghast.

dialogues.speaker: KELLY
dialogues.text: Maybe it’s all a big joke to you, but Jeff’s talked the whole town into thinking you’re going to save us from this “Guan-Di.”

dialogues.speaker: BRUCE
dialogues.text: Right. And?

dialogues.speaker: KELLY
dialogues.text: Far as I can tell, you’re totally full of shit. (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Verheiden "My Name Is Bruce" 4/2/06 53.

dialogues.speaker: CONTINUED
dialogues.text: Bruce is taken aback by that. There’s a long pause as he considers the insult, then he breaks out laughing!

dialogues.speaker: BRUCE
dialogues.text: I get it! You’re the meet-cute!

dialogues.speaker: KELLY
dialogues.text: The what?

dialogues.speaker: BRUCE
dialogues.text: Mills thought of everything! He’s a genius! Chortling, Bruce wanders across the bar, leaving Kelly baffled. The Mayor comes over, mindful of her attitude, still hoping and praying that Bruce can save them.

dialogues.speaker: MAYOR
dialogues.text: Kelly, I know you don’t much like the stranger, but we need someone to go up against the demon. The Mayor looks over at Bruce, almost as dubious as Kelly.

dialogues.speaker: MAYOR, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: And right now, in an absolutely tragic turn of events, he’s the best we've got. Bruce looks back at Kelly and the Mayor and laughs even harder. OFF Kelly’s befuddlement...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The sun sets, the dazzling orange glow growing dim...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: As the last rays of the sun set, rocks begin to move in front of the old cave, as if something is stirring inside. Suddenly, a

dialogues.speaker: BLOOD-SOAKED SWORD
dialogues.text: splits through the stones. The Guan-Di emerging for another night of vengeance...  Verheiden "My Name Is Bruce" 4/2/06 54.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: We HEAR a loud YEEEE-HAWWW, revealing the festivities are in full swing. A band (The Smithereens?) is playing full volume while Townfolk drink and dance.
